document.docAuthor: Van Dam, Matthew H. & O’Brien, Charles W.
document.masterDocTitle: Review of the genus Miloderes Casey, 1888 (Coleoptera: Curculionidae: Entiminae), with desciptions of three new species

mods:titleInfo.mods:title: Review of the genus Miloderes Casey, 1888 (Coleoptera: Curculionidae: Entiminae), with desciptions of three new species

bibRefCitation.author: Tanner
bibRefCitation.refString: Tanner, V. (1974) Description of new species of Miloderes Casey, with comments on other species of the genus (Coleoptera: Curculionidae). The Great Basin Naturalist, 34, 291 - 296.

paragraph.treatmentCitationGroup:
Miloderes tingi
Tanner, 1974
: 293
. Holotype female, CA: San Bernardino Co. Essex,
29 April 1937
, P.C. Ting, M. Cazier, examined ( BYU ).
O’Brien & Wibmer, 1982
: 60
.

subSubSection.paragraph: Description. Body clothed in long dense setae. Head with scales on frons convex. Pronotum without vitta, lateral margins strongly convex. Elytra dark green to light green to gray and brown pattern to blue and brown pattern to pearl color. Legs with front tibial shape flat expanded, tibial brush elongate; hind tibial apex truncate. Median lobe curved. Endophallus with basal lobe not recurved and distended, dorsal lobe absent, distal projection absent, endophallus terminal not recurved, median ventral lobe present, subapical lobe resting on posterior dorsal surface, middle thick, ventral apical lobe absent, transfer apparatus not sclerotized or absent. Spermatheca with basal lobes of relatively equal length.

Distribution. (
Fig. 19
) This species is found in sand dunes of the southern Mojave Desert primarily along the Mojave River watershed. Distribution is partially sympatric with
M. setosus
.

Intra- and interspecific morphological variation. The color variation of
M. tingi
is quite extensive, ranging from nearly pearl white to dark blue, with green in between (
Fig. 9
G). This may have led to many of these color variations being labeled as new species in museum collections. Each population is typically represented by a single color morph, with occasional color variation occurring in a minority of individuals. For example those near Barstow, California tend to be green in color, while those of the Cronise Dry Lake (Basin Road) tend to be more copper in color, although green color morphs occur there as well. The type specimen from Essex, California exhibited characteristics typical of smaller individuals in other populations. In these individuals, the lateral margins of the elytra tend to be more parallel than in larger specimens. Additionally the apical comb on the front tibia, present as a narrow row of fine setae (
Fig. 7
A), is aligned more closely to the longitudinal axis of the tibia than in larger specimens (
Fig. 7
C). Specimens from 2mi . N of Essex had an endophallus lacking a sclerotized transfer apparatus as in all other
M. tingi
examined. Males from the type locality are unknown.
